turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Rho-associated protein kinase.
turn.1: What are the similarities between RAF1 and SRC?
turn.2: They have 65% amino acid sequences in common and 92% homology within their kinase domains.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: ROCKs are homologous to other metazoan kinases such as myotonic dystrophy kinase (DMPK), DMPK-related cell division control protein 42 (Cdc42)-binding kinases (MRCK) and citron kinase.
turn.5: What are the differences between them?
turn.6: All of these kinases are composed of a N-terminal kinase domain, a coiled-coil structure and other functional motifs at the C-terminus   ROCK is a downstream effector molecule of the Rho GTPase Rho that increases ROCK kinase activity when bound to it.
turn.7: What does it do once it's released?
turn.8: Autoinhibition ROCK activity is regulated by the disruption of an intramolecular autoinhibition.
turn.9: What are some other interesting aspects of this article?
turn.10: In general, the structure of ROCK proteins consists of an N-terminal kinase domain, a coiled-coiled region and a PH domain containing a cystein-rich domain (CRD) at the C-terminal.
turn.11: Is there anything else that is important to know?
turn.12: A Rho-binding domain (RBD) is located in close proximity just in front of the PH domain.
